Introduction to viparc

Marc Choisy

2019-01-10

Source: vignettes/viparc.Rmd
viparc.Rmd

Packages

> library(viparc)
> library(dplyr)

Heatmap figure

Heatmap of the surveillance disease and drug usage in several farms for a number of weeks:

> data("chcknfarms")
> chcknfarms %>%
+   filter(CYCLE == 1) %>%
+   transmute(space   = FARMCODE,
+             time    = WEEK,
+             disease = SRespiratory,
+             drug    = AntibioticUse) %>%
+   heat_map()

Note that the input data frame to heat_map should have 4 variables named space, time, disease and drug.

Identifying weeks with no AMU

Let’s consider for example the following vector of AMU:

> amu <- rep(rep(c(TRUE, FALSE), 6), c(7, 2, 1, 2, 3, 1, 2, 1, 1, 1, 1, 3))

See this example:

> data.frame(amu) %>%
+   mutate(
+     with_amu = amu,
+     wout_amu = no_amu(amu, 1)) %>%
+   select(-amu)
#>    with_amu wout_amu
#> 1      TRUE       NA
#> 2      TRUE    FALSE
#> 3      TRUE    FALSE
#> 4      TRUE    FALSE
#> 5      TRUE    FALSE
#> 6      TRUE    FALSE
#> 7      TRUE    FALSE
#> 8     FALSE    FALSE
#> 9     FALSE     TRUE
#> 10     TRUE    FALSE
#> 11    FALSE    FALSE
#> 12    FALSE     TRUE
#> 13     TRUE    FALSE
#> 14     TRUE    FALSE
#> 15     TRUE    FALSE
#> 16    FALSE    FALSE
#> 17     TRUE    FALSE
#> 18     TRUE    FALSE
#> 19    FALSE    FALSE
#> 20     TRUE    FALSE
#> 21    FALSE    FALSE
#> 22     TRUE    FALSE
#> 23    FALSE    FALSE
#> 24    FALSE     TRUE
#> 25    FALSE     TRUE

Note that, as expected, the only combination that we cannot have on any row is c(TRUE, TRUE). Then, if one wants to discriminate any week either into AMU or no-AMU, the code will have to be:

> data.frame(amu) %>%
+   mutate(
+     with_amu = amu,
+     wout_amu = no_amu(amu, 1)) %>%
+   select(-amu) %>% 
+   filter(with_amu + wout_amu > 0) %>% 
+   transmute(amu = with_amu)
#>      amu
#> 1   TRUE
#> 2   TRUE
#> 3   TRUE
#> 4   TRUE
#> 5   TRUE
#> 6   TRUE
#> 7  FALSE
#> 8   TRUE
#> 9  FALSE
#> 10  TRUE
#> 11  TRUE
#> 12  TRUE
#> 13  TRUE
#> 14  TRUE
#> 15  TRUE
#> 16  TRUE
#> 17 FALSE
#> 18 FALSE

Looking for the effect of AMU on disease

Let’s consider a data set that could look like this:

> (dataset <- data.frame(
+   amu = c(rep(TRUE, 4), rep(FALSE, 5), TRUE, rep(FALSE, 6), TRUE,
+           FALSE, TRUE, rep(FALSE, 4), TRUE, FALSE),
+   disease = c(rep(TRUE, 3), FALSE, TRUE, FALSE, rep(TRUE, 2), FALSE,
+               rep(TRUE, 2), rep(FALSE, 3), rep(TRUE, 2), rep(FALSE, 3),
+               TRUE, rep(FALSE, 2), rep(TRUE, 3))
+ ))
#>      amu disease
#> 1   TRUE    TRUE
#> 2   TRUE    TRUE
#> 3   TRUE    TRUE
#> 4   TRUE   FALSE
#> 5  FALSE    TRUE
#> 6  FALSE   FALSE
#> 7  FALSE    TRUE
#> 8  FALSE    TRUE
#> 9  FALSE   FALSE
#> 10  TRUE    TRUE
#> 11 FALSE    TRUE
#> 12 FALSE   FALSE
#> 13 FALSE   FALSE
#> 14 FALSE   FALSE
#> 15 FALSE    TRUE
#> 16 FALSE    TRUE
#> 17  TRUE   FALSE
#> 18 FALSE   FALSE
#> 19  TRUE   FALSE
#> 20 FALSE    TRUE
#> 21 FALSE   FALSE
#> 22 FALSE   FALSE
#> 23 FALSE    TRUE
#> 24  TRUE    TRUE
#> 25 FALSE    TRUE

Among the weeks with no diseases, we want to compare 2 groups of weeks:

  • the weeks \(i\) with no AMU as well as no AMU either on week \(i - 1\);
  • the weeks with AMU

and for each of these 2 groups we want to count the number of weeks \(j\) for which a disease was observed at week \(j + 1\) or \(j + 2\).

To make it clear, note that here we are thus eliminating from the analysis

  • all the weeks \(k\) with no AMU but with AMU on week \(k - 1\) and
  • all the weeks with disease.

The R code for that would be:

> dataset %>% 
+   mutate(no_amu = no_amu(amu, 1),              # no AMU on weeks i-1 and i
+          diseas = any_disease(disease, 2)) %>% # disease on weeks i+1 or i+2
+   na.exclude() %>% 
+   filter(! disease,                            # removes weeks with disease
+          amu + no_amu ) %>%                    # removes weeks with no AMU but...
+   mutate(amu = ! no_amu) %>%                   # ... with AMU the week before.
+   select(-disease, -no_amu)  %>% 
+   table() %>% 
+   fisher.test()
#> 
#>  Fisher's Exact Test for Count Data
#> 
#> data:  .
#> p-value = 1
#> alternative hypothesis: true odds ratio is not equal to 1
#> 95 percent confidence interval:
#>   0.003660373 39.142615141
#> sample estimates:
#> odds ratio 
#>  0.3779644

Indexing the week in a sequence

See how functions index() and fill_gaps() can be used to do the job:

> dataset %>%
+   mutate(amu_week = index(amu),
+          disease2 = fill_gaps(disease),
+          disease2_week = index(disease2)) %>% 
+   select(amu, amu_week, disease, disease2, disease2_week)
#> Le chargement a nécessité le package : magrittr
#>      amu amu_week disease disease2 disease2_week
#> 1   TRUE        1    TRUE     TRUE             1
#> 2   TRUE        2    TRUE     TRUE             2
#> 3   TRUE        3    TRUE     TRUE             3
#> 4   TRUE        4   FALSE     TRUE             4
#> 5  FALSE        1    TRUE     TRUE             5
#> 6  FALSE        2   FALSE     TRUE             6
#> 7  FALSE        3    TRUE     TRUE             7
#> 8  FALSE        4    TRUE     TRUE             8
#> 9  FALSE        5   FALSE     TRUE             9
#> 10  TRUE        1    TRUE     TRUE            10
#> 11 FALSE        1    TRUE     TRUE            11
#> 12 FALSE        2   FALSE    FALSE             1
#> 13 FALSE        3   FALSE    FALSE             2
#> 14 FALSE        4   FALSE    FALSE             3
#> 15 FALSE        5    TRUE     TRUE             1
#> 16 FALSE        6    TRUE     TRUE             2
#> 17  TRUE        1   FALSE    FALSE             1
#> 18 FALSE        1   FALSE    FALSE             2
#> 19  TRUE        1   FALSE    FALSE             3
#> 20 FALSE        1    TRUE     TRUE             1
#> 21 FALSE        2   FALSE    FALSE             1
#> 22 FALSE        3   FALSE    FALSE             2
#> 23 FALSE        4    TRUE     TRUE             1
#> 24  TRUE        1    TRUE     TRUE             2
#> 25 FALSE        1    TRUE     TRUE             3

Then, you can extend this in a longer pipeline:

> dataset %>%
+   mutate(amu_week = index(amu),
+          disease = fill_gaps(disease),
+          disease_week = ifelse(disease, index(disease), NA),
+          disease_start = disease_week < 2,
+          amu_event = ifelse(amu,
+                             ifelse(amu_week > 1, "D", "S"),
+                             ifelse(amu_week > 1, "N", "A")))
#>      amu disease amu_week disease_week disease_start amu_event
#> 1   TRUE    TRUE        1            1          TRUE         S
#> 2   TRUE    TRUE        2            2         FALSE         D
#> 3   TRUE    TRUE        3            3         FALSE         D
#> 4   TRUE    TRUE        4            4         FALSE         D
#> 5  FALSE    TRUE        1            5         FALSE         A
#> 6  FALSE    TRUE        2            6         FALSE         N
#> 7  FALSE    TRUE        3            7         FALSE         N
#> 8  FALSE    TRUE        4            8         FALSE         N
#> 9  FALSE    TRUE        5            9         FALSE         N
#> 10  TRUE    TRUE        1           10         FALSE         S
#> 11 FALSE    TRUE        1           11         FALSE         A
#> 12 FALSE   FALSE        2           NA            NA         N
#> 13 FALSE   FALSE        3           NA            NA         N
#> 14 FALSE   FALSE        4           NA            NA         N
#> 15 FALSE    TRUE        5            1          TRUE         N
#> 16 FALSE    TRUE        6            2         FALSE         N
#> 17  TRUE   FALSE        1           NA            NA         S
#> 18 FALSE   FALSE        1           NA            NA         A
#> 19  TRUE   FALSE        1           NA            NA         S
#> 20 FALSE    TRUE        1            1          TRUE         A
#> 21 FALSE   FALSE        2           NA            NA         N
#> 22 FALSE   FALSE        3           NA            NA         N
#> 23 FALSE    TRUE        4            1          TRUE         N
#> 24  TRUE    TRUE        1            2         FALSE         S
#> 25 FALSE    TRUE        1            3         FALSE         A
